A story that caught my attention. I have kinda wondered how parades worked with regards to if you have to attend being in the police of a firefighter (in the parade as opposed protecting it). Any thoughts?
 
 http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,292442,00.html

post_info.post_title: Firefighters File Complaint regarding Gay Pride Parade

thelmoose

A story that caught my attention. I have kinda wondered how parades worked with regards to if you have to attend being in the police of a firefighter (in the parade as opposed protecting it). Any thoughts?
 
 http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,292442,00.html

 
 I didn't know the police or firefighter marched in parades. Is the only one they are required to march in?
foundit66

I didn't know the police or firefighter marched in parades. Is the only one they are required to march in?

 
 I've seen photos of cops in the big Saint Patrick's day parades.
 http://www.nyc-photo-gallery.com/HiRES_St-Patricks-Day-01.htm
 
 Don't know about "required".
Steeeeve

I didn't know the police or firefighter marched in parades. Is the only one they are required to march in?

 
 They do fourth of July parades and things like that. Sometimes they do parades for thanksgiving or for a big Bowl game or something. 
 
 I saw one at the Chik-Fil-A bowl parade last year.
thelmoose

They do fourth of July parades and things like that. Sometimes they do parades for thanksgiving or for a big Bowl game or something. 
 
 I saw one at the Chik-Fil-A bowl parade last year.

 
 Well if they are required to march in the other parades as part of their job and the fire chief picks this one, I don't see why they should be excluded. They are public servants and work for all citizens. 
 
 On the other hand, I hate for things to come to this. 
 
 On the other hand, the "harassment" is merely to watch citizens behaving the way citizens sometimes do in public. 
 
 "forced to see men in tight shorts dancing provocatively and other men kissing and hugging wearing sexually suggestive material on T-shirts" (What if they had to put out a fire at a gay bar? Could they object to that part of their job?)
 
 This does not sound all that harassing to me. I think that firefighters and cops see much worse in other aspects of their job every day. 
 
 What if they found the Irish objectionable, could they skip the St. Paddy's parade?
sinjin
Why not just put undercover officers in the crowd and write some citations for lewd behavior?
Jo Bennett
Reading between the lines, it looks like the real issue is that the firefighters didn't want to be seen as in favour of gay rights.
Kronus

Participation in a parade ought to be voluntary, they probably shouldn't have been forced to march. On the other hand:
 
 "In statements filed with the state, the men said that along the parade route, they were subjected to offensive and lewd comments such as, "You can put out my fire," and saw men blowing kisses at them. "
 
 If the firefighers think those comments are actionable then they desperately need to grow a thicker skin. I've got to assume that it's the fact that men were making these comments that got them upset. I find it hard to imagine any straight guy going to court over a woman blowing kisses at him. If I were defending this case I might argue that harassment should be harassment regardless of the genders of the people involved. Either something is allowed or not; the gender of the people involved shouldn't have any bearing.
samiinh

Participation in a parade ought to be voluntary, they probably shouldn't have been forced to march. On the other hand:
 
 "In statements filed with the state, the men said that along the parade route, they were subjected to offensive and lewd comments such as, "You can put out my fire," and saw men blowing kisses at them. "
 
 If the firefighers think those comments are actionable then they desperately need to grow a thicker skin. I've got to assume that it's the fact that men were making these comments that got them upset. I find it hard to imagine any straight guy going to court over a woman blowing kisses at him. If I were defending this case I might argue that harassment should be harassment regardless of the genders of the people involved. Either something is allowed or not; the gender of the people involved shouldn't have any bearing.

 
 Fireman can be hot.
Matthew S
So would a gay firefighter be exempt from attending a religious activity were they preach that gays are evil?
Bassman

So would a gay firefighter be exempt from attending a religious activity were they preach that gays are evil?

 I don't see why not?
GiantOreo

They do fourth of July parades and things like that. Sometimes they do parades for thanksgiving or for a big Bowl game or something. 
 
 I saw one at the Chik-Fil-A bowl parade last year.

 
 
 Yes, there are several 4th of July and Thanksgiving parades near me that they do (or at least have some sort of participation in.
 
 On a side note, man, I love Chick-Fil-A: some of the best chicken sandwiches I've ever had. :p
Matthew S

Another perspective besides fauxnews
 http://gayorbit.net/?p=7597
 
 
There you are. That’s the real reason they’re suing. Some gay guy called the driver a hottie. The firefighter decides to get back at the city for forcing him into a festival of debauchery by suing them for harrassment.

 
 
The Thomas More Law Center, a conservative Christian legal organization based in Michigan, is helping represent the plaintiffs.
 
 That’s all you need to know, of course. If it was really sexual harrassment, they’d have just hired regular lawyers, not a group committed to the fight against the “homosexual agenda!”
 
 [Fire department spokesman Maurice] Luque said the agency’s engines had participated in San Diego’s LGBT Pride Festival for the past 15 years and never had any complaints.
 
 In 15 years, no complaints, until the fundie brigade was told to drive.

 
 15 years they have firefighters in the parade. emoticon_rolleyes
foundit66

"forced to see men in tight shorts dancing provocatively and other men kissing and hugging wearing sexually suggestive material on T-shirts" (What if they had to put out a fire at a gay bar? Could they object to that part of their job?)
 
 This does not sound all that harassing to me. I think that firefighters and cops see much worse in other aspects of their job every day.

 And the "sexually suggestive material on T-Shirts"??
 The first one sounded devoid of "sexually suggestive". Probably some chubby bear wearing a "girth and mirth" t-shirt to let people know he was round and gay.
 I'd be curious to know what idiotic presumption of "sexually suggestive" this firefighter had in mind.
 
 And the second was just a slogan to put on a condom, if it's "suggestive" at all.
 
 I've been to San Diego gay pride. They are talking about stereo-types. The average person in the crowd is NOTHING like they cry about.
 These firefighters are the real drama queens here....
robbie0517

Another perspective besides fauxnews
 http://gayorbit.net/?p=7597
 
 
 
 
 
 15 years they have firefighters in the parade. emoticon_rolleyes

 
 The article also notes that in addition to their participating for 15 years, they have never had any complaints. I thought that was interesting. 
 
 Also, In the official complaint I read from the original post, another firefighter that attended mentioned that he didn't see anything like the incidents described happening. I think they just see an opportunity to make a buck myself.
Steeeeve

Well if they are required to march in the other parades as part of their job and the fire chief picks this one, I don't see why they should be excluded. They are public servants and work for all citizens. 
 
 On the other hand, I hate for things to come to this. 
 
 On the other hand, the "harassment" is merely to watch citizens behaving the way citizens sometimes do in public. 
 
 "forced to see men in tight shorts dancing provocatively and other men kissing and hugging wearing sexually suggestive material on T-shirts" (What if they had to put out a fire at a gay bar? Could they object to that part of their job?)
 
 This does not sound all that harassing to me. I think that firefighters and cops see much worse in other aspects of their job every day. 
 
 What if they found the Irish objectionable, could they skip the St. Paddy's parade?

 
 I didn't think you could be forced into any parade but I guess I was wrong.
 
 I think the harassment might have a chance because being a parade is not a significant part of being a firefighter.
robbie0517

Ok, I read the entire official complaint. 
 If everything mentioned in the reports is true, then I do believe they were treated unfairly and even sexually harrassed. 
 I went to the pride parade here in Columbus this year. I hadn't gone in years, I'm not that crazy about them but my friend wanted to go. 
 There can be some people that act inappropriately. To be honest, they are an embarrassment to me as I do not behave in that way at all. 
 They are the minority however. 
 
 On a side note though, I bet if everything described were coming from women, they wouldn't be suing, they would be bragging about it for months.
